title: Best Toffee Ever - Super Easy Recipe
description: This toffee is layered with crunchy almonds and chocolate and tastes rich and buttery. It's a simple recipe and perfect for holiday gifts and parties.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Desserts Candy Recipes Toffee Recipes Best Toffee Ever - Super Easy 4.7 (1,418) 1,224 Reviews 187 Photos This rich, buttery toffee is layered with smooth chocolate and topped with crunchy almonds. The recipe is easy to make and perfect for holiday gift giving or bake sales. I always get compliments and requests for more of this toffee candy. Submitted by FUNKYSEAMONKEY Updated on November 25, 2024 Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen The Allrecipes Test Kitchen staff are a team of culinary pros who make and vet recipes using only equipment you'd find in a home kitchen. Staff credentials vary but include training at the Culinary Institute of America; kitchen stints in fine dining restaurants; and countless hours in the test kitchen itself. Meet the Allrecipes Test Kitchen Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 187 187 187 187 Prep Time: 10 mins Cook Time: 30 mins Additional Time: 1 hr Total Time: 1 hr 40 mins Servings: 32 Yield: 2 1/2 pounds of toffee Jump to Nutrition Facts Jump to recipe Need an edible gift that'll please everyone on your list? Look no further than toffee! This top-rated toffee recipe is beloved by the Allrecipes community because it's easy, quick, and absolutely irresistible. What Is Toffee? Toffee is a candy made by caramelizing sugar with butter. The mixture is heated until it reaches the hard crack stage (at least 300 degrees F), hardened, then broken into pieces. Toffee vs. Caramel Toffee and caramel have some similarities, but they have a few key differences. Caramel often contains milk or cream, which gives it a thicker and creamier consistency. The candies are also heated to different temperatures during the cooking process. What Is Toffee Made Of? Make this easy toffee with just five ingredients: Butter: This sweet and crunchy toffee starts with four sticks of melted butter.Sugar: Two cups of sugar add the perfect amount of sweetness.Salt: A pinch of salt enhances the other flavors.Chocolate chips: Melted semisweet chocolate chips are spread over the toffee for an extra layer of deliciousness.Almonds: Almonds lend welcome crunch. You can substitute walnuts or pecans, if desired. How to Make Toffee You'll find the full, step-by-step recipe below — but here's a brief overview of what you can expect when you make this toffee candy: Melt butter in a saucepan with sugar and salt.Bring the mixture to a boil. Cook until it's dark amber and 285 degrees F.Pour the toffee onto a prepared baking sheet.Sprinkle the chocolate chips onto the toffee, let soften, and spread in an even layer.Sprinkle the nuts over the chocolate.Let harden in the refrigerator. When the toffee is hard, break into pieces. How to Store Toffee Store homemade toffee in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week or in the fridge for up to two weeks. Can You Freeze Toffee? Yes! You can freeze toffee for up to three months. Arrange the hardened toffee pieces in a single layer on a baking sheet, cover, then freeze for at least a few hours or up to overnight. When the toffee is frozen, transfer the pieces to zip-top storage bags (make sure to squeeze out the excess air) or another freezer-safe container. Wrap in foil for extra protection. Thaw in the refrigerator overnight. Allrecipes Community Tips and Praise "Super simple to make," according to jstbeyondreach. "Took almost no time to put together, and was a huge crowd-pleaser. I used half light butter and half regular butter. Worked great and was super creamy." "This is my go-to recipe for toffee," says Karen Griffiths. "I must have had 20 failures over the years, but since I have been using this recipe I have had a good batch each time. I think the trick is cooking it on medium. DON'T RUSH IT!" "This really was very easy to make," raves Em. "It was my first attempt at toffee and I was a little nervous, but it turned out great. As tempting as it is to keep stirring it, it really does make a big difference to just let it simmer." Editorial contributions by Corey Williams Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 32 servings 2 cups unsalted butter 2 cups white sugar ¼ teaspoon salt 2 cups semisweet chocolate chips 1 cup finely chopped almonds Directions Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Combine butter, sugar, and salt in a large, heavy-bottomed saucepan over medium heat. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Stir constantly in one direction until butter is melted, about 5 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Meanwhile, line a 9x13-inch baking dish with a sheet of parchment paper, letting it overhang two sides of the dish. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Once the butter has melted, stop stirring and bring mixture to a boil. Once boiling, cook, stirring only 2 to 3 times, until it turns a dark amber color and the temperature reaches 285 degrees F (137 degrees C) on a candy thermometer, 20 to 30 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Immediately pour toffee into the prepared baking dish. Sprinkle chocolate chips on top and let sit until they soften, 1 to 2 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Use a spatula to spread softened chocolate into a thin, even layer. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Sprinkle nuts over the chocolate and press down slightly; wearing a plastic bag over your hand will minimize the mess. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place toffee in the refrigerator until set, about 1 hour. Lift hardened toffee out of the baking dish with the parchment paper. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Break into pieces and store in an airtight container. Meredith Food Studio Recipe Tip You can use chopped walnuts or pecans instead of almonds if preferred. Add Your Photo Photos of Best Toffee Ever - Super Easy 01 of 187 Photo by  Meredith Food Studio 02 of 187 Photo by  Arlene Starr Smith 01/14/2025 A keeper! Great flavors Easy to follow Worth the effort I love to bake, am 57, and had never made toffee before because I thought it was too difficult. What?? Where has this recipe been my whole life?? Super easy. I stirred (one direction) while melting the butter and making sure it was combined with the sugar. I then left it on medium (not on the power boil burner) and did not stir again. I checked the temp with my battery operated thermometer and the crunch in a bowl of ice water. It went from 290 to 300 rather quickly, so I snatched it off in a panic and poured it into the pan over the chocolate and parchment paper. (I had melted some of the chocolate chips on the parchment paper in the oven and spread it over the area the toffee would go, then stuck it in the fridge until set. I poured the hot toffee over that set chocolate.) I then proceeded to add more chocolate over the top as instructed in the recipe. I left it in the fridge until the chocolate on top was set, then left out on the table overnight so the chocolate would not be cold and brittle when I broke it up. It is perfect. I actually made it to use in a copycat Levain coffee toffee cookie recipe, but have definitely been sneaking bites. :) Also, I left off the almonds for the sake of the cookie, but when I make it again for general consumption, I will have to put them on. :D 03 of 187 Photo by  CaringDove2319 12/14/2024 A keeper! Easy to follow Who knew that when Megan Orsini commented 18 years ago, she’d help so many! I followed her instructions and mine came out great. I only did a half batch though and I added a shot of espresso to my butter and sugar mix as it was melting! Came out SO yummy! Will definitely be making more of this toffee! 04 of 187 Photo by  LankyPeel3047 11/09/2024 We used to be gifted a box of commercially made almond toffee every year for Christmas and I wanted to try and duplicate that recipe. This one comes pretty darn close! I live in a humid area and cooked it to between 290 and 300 degrees and used a 10X15 inch pan, otherwise I followed the recipe carefully. It only took about 15 minutes to get the mixture up to temperature after the butter was melted. I used sliced almonds, chopped most of them and left some unchopped as suggested by another reviewer. This toffee is delicious! I'll be making it again. 05 of 187 Photo by  Sandra Terry 09/08/2024 A keeper! Great flavors Easy to follow Crowd-pleaser Family favorite Worth the effort Easy and very good! Will be making this several times and especially for the holidays! 06 of 187 Photo by  Michael Bynum 01/09/2024 This is my second time making this toffee. I used a bigger pan to make it a little thinner. Instead of the almonds, I use roasted salted pistachio nuts, and a little bit more than 2 cups, a bittersweet chocolate. 07 of 187 Photo by  Shannon Walsh Orlowski 01/07/2024 I whisk mine instead of stirring and it comes out amazing!!! 08 of 187 Photo by  Brian Stopford 08/28/2023 I've made it a few times now and in addition to the listed ingredients I added 2TBL corn syrup, 1. tsp vanilla and 2.TBL water. I add the vanilla at the end right before pouring the mixture onto the baking sheet. 09 of 187 Photo by  ChirpyDuck8060 08/27/2023 I made these yummy 😋 treats but I used coconut sugar and a bit of almond milk for a caramelly texture and Omgoodness YUM. The coconut sugar didn't change the color or taste.. Making them again today 10 of 187 Photo by  SweetDip3070 12/22/2022 Seen some negative reviews from "experts". This was my first attempt at making toffee.
